summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, addressing proposed redactions to motions in limine and related exhibits. The judge finds some proposed redactions overbroad and orders the parties to submit more tailored proposals by November 4, 2021.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in this court order.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, ruling on proposed redactions to motions in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an order denying some proposed redactions as overbroad and requiring the parties to submit more tailored proposals.

events.title: Deadline for Redaction Proposals
events.description: The parties are ordered to submit revised, more tailored redaction proposals to the court.

keyFacts: Judge Alison J. Nathan found some proposed redactions to motions in the Ghislaine Maxwell case to be overbroad under the Second Circuit's Lugosch test.
The Court specifically denied the Government's request to redact section ten of its motion in limine.
The Court also stated it would not permit redactions pertaining to general descriptions of evidence or anticipated testimony, deeming them unnecessary to protect privacy interests.
The parties were ordered to submit more tailored redaction proposals by November 4, 2021, with the Defendant's and Government's proposals highlighted in different colors.
